questions.text:
A 15-year-old girl comes to the physician for a well-child examination. She feels well. Her father has coronary artery disease and hypertension. Her mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypercholesterolemia, and had a myocardial infarction at the age of 52 years. She is at the 25th percentile for height and above the 95th percentile for weight. Her BMI is 32 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 99/min, and blood pressure is 140/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Random serum studies show:


Glucose
160 mg/dL


Creatinine
0.8 mg/dL


Total cholesterol
245 mg/dL


 HDL-cholesterol

29 mg/dL


 LDL-cholesterol
168 mg/dL


Triglycerides
240 mg/dL


In addition to regular aerobic physical activity, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Appropriately supervised weight training is safe and beneficial for children older than approx. 7–8 years, and physical activity of any kind is part of the first-line treatment for metabolic syndrome. However, children should begin weight training at low intensity (e.g., very light weight) in order to learn appropriate technique and reduce the risk of injury. Beginning with high-intensity weight training would put this child at unacceptably high risk of injury.

B) CORRECT:

Weight loss is the most important therapeutic goal for patients with metabolic syndrome, and lifestyle modifications like a more balanced diet and increased physical activity are the most effective means of achieving weight loss. Dietary interventions for children and adolescents with obesity should not consist of strict diet regimens but rather focus on the long-term promotion of healthy eating behaviors such as increasing the consumption of fruit and vegetables and minimizing the consumption of sugar-sweetened beverages and saturated fats. Reducing body weight and abdominal fat subsequently increases insulin sensitivity and reduces blood pressure and lipids, and there may also be long-term effects as weight loss may help in preventing or delaying the onset of cardiovascular disease and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Finally, the implementation of lifestyle changes avoids the possible side effects of pharmacotherapy. If lifestyle modification fails to resolve the laboratory abnormalities within approx. 6 months, pharmacotherapy (e.g., statins) is indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

Fenofibrate is used in both children and adults to lower triglyceride levels. While this patient has hypertriglyceridemia, another step in management is indicated first.

D) INCORRECT:

Atorvastatin can be used to treat hypercholesterolemia in children. The decision to initiate medical therapy in children should be based on LDL cholesterol levels, traditional ASCVD risk factors, family history of premature ASCVD, and the presence of high- or medium-risk conditions (e.g., diabetes, chronic kidney disease). This patient has both increased LDL cholesterol levels and a positive family history of ASCVD. However, before initiating medical therapy, a different intervention should be first considered.

E) INCORRECT:

Metformin is commonly used to treat type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM), for which this patient is at increased risk given her obesity. While she has elevated random blood glucose (≥ 140 mg/dL), she does not yet meet the criteria for the diagnosis of T2DM (i.e., fasting glucose ≥ 126 mg/dL or glucose ≥ 200 mg/dL 2 hours after oral glucose tolerance test). Although further evaluation of her random glucose test is warranted, metformin is not indicated at this time. Even if T2DM is diagnosed, metformin would only be indicated after lifestyle modifications have been exhausted.
questions.hint: This patient has hypertension, hypertriglyceridemia, and low HDL, fulfilling the diagnostic criteria for metabolic syndrome. She also has obesity, increased total cholesterol and LDL, and an increased random blood glucose level.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man comes to the office as a new patient. He feels well but is worried about his health because his father died of myocardial infarction 2 weeks ago at the age of 80. The patient has not been evaluated by a physician in 15 years. He does not follow any specific diet; he usually eats sandwiches at work and fried chicken or a burger for dinner. He says that he has been struggling with a stressful project at work recently. His mother was diagnosed with hypertension at the age of 45. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years but quit 20 years ago. He drinks one to two beers daily. He is 181 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 80 kg (176 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 127/82 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender; waist circumference is 103 cm. Fasting serum studies show:


Cholesterol, total
251 mg/dL


 HDL-cholesterol
40 mg/dL


 LDL-cholesterol
170 mg/dL


Triglycerides
205 mg/dL


Glucose
120 mg/dL


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Schedule a follow-up visit to repeat fasting glucose and lipid profile testing in 3 months

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Metformin is an oral hypoglycemic agent that improves glucose tolerance by increasing insulin sensitivity. Although metformin may be considered for some individuals with impaired glucose tolerance, the use of medication to prevent type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) in patients with metabolic syndrome is only considered if nonpharmacologic interventions fail. Treatment with metformin should be initiated if the patient is diagnosed with T2DM (fasting glucose ≥ 126 mg/dL).

B) INCORRECT:

Fenofibrate is used in the treatment of hypertriglyceridemia. However, fibrates are only added for moderate to severe hypertriglyceridemia (500–999 mg/dL).

C) CORRECT:

Lifestyle modifications that assist in weight reduction, such as increasing physical activity and adopting a healthier diet, are the primary treatments for metabolic syndrome. This patient's elevated fasting serum glucose suggests insulin resistance, which commonly develops in individuals with abdominal obesity. Increased physical activity and weight loss improve insulin sensitivity, which prevents the onset of type 2 diabetes mellitus and other associated conditions (e.g., hypertension, dyslipidemia) and lowers the risk of cardiovascular disease. Patients should engage in at least 30 minutes of moderate aerobic activity (e.g., brisk walking) 5–7 times a week.

Diagnostic criteria for metabolic syndrome include insulin resistance (fasting glucose ≥ 100 mg/dL), elevated blood pressure (systolic ≥ 130 mm Hg and/or diastolic ≥ 85 mm Hg), elevated triglycerides (≥ 150 mg/dL), decreased HDL (< 40 mg/dL in men, < 50 mg/dL in women), and increased waist circumference (≥ 102 cm in men, ≥ 88 cm in women). Metabolic syndrome is diagnosed if ≥ 3 of these criteria are present. Waist circumference rather than BMI is relevant in diagnosing metabolic syndrome; although patients with metabolic syndrome are often overweight or obese, they can have a normal BMI.

D) INCORRECT:

Although regular follow-up is important in patients with metabolic syndrome, measures should be initiated immediately to reduce the risk of cardiovascular complications.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient has some risk factors for CAD (e.g., age, sex, smoking, hypercholesterolemia), but cardiac stress testing is not indicated as a screening test for asymptomatic patients. Indications for cardiac stress testing include chronic stable angina, provocation of arrhythmia, and evaluation of patients who experience other exertional symptoms (e.g., palpitations, syncope).
questions.hint: This patient presents with elevated serum fasting concentrations of glucose (≥ 100 mg/dL) and triglycerides (≥ 150 mg/dL), and increased waist circumference (≥ 102 cm), which are diagnostic of metabolic syndrome.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man with hypertension presents for follow-up after a routine screening examination 6 months ago. Advice at the initial appointment focused on intensive diet modification, increased exercise, and smoking cessation. The patient reports that he has cut his smoking from about 30 cigarettes daily to 15. He has been unable to lose weight. He has no history of alcohol use and no risk factors for hepatitis. Current medications include aspirin 81 mg daily and hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg daily.
On physical examination, his blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg, his BMI is 34, and his waist circumference is 109 cm. There is no hepatosplenomegaly.
Fasting laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range



Alanine aminotransferase (U/liter)

Aspartate aminotransferase (U/liter)
48

Total cholesterol (mg/dL)

The patient’s estimated 10-year risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease is 15%.
In addition to continued lifestyle modification, which one of the following medications is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient’s blood pressure is at goal, making lisinopril unnecessary.

B) INCORRECT:

Fibrates and niacin are not first-line agents for lowering LDL-cholesterol levels. Niacin may exacerbate glucose intolerance.

C) CORRECT:

This patient smokes cigarettes and has metabolic syndrome, as evidenced by his abdominal obesity, hypertension history, elevated fasting glucose level, hypertriglyceridemia, and low level of HDL cholesterol. He is likely to have nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) as well, given his mildly elevated alanine and aspartate aminotransferase levels. There is some evidence that NAFLD may be associated with increased risk for cardiovascular disease, independent of the risk associated with metabolic syndrome. Current recommendations for treating NAFLD include losing at least 3% to 5% of body weight (ideally 7% to 10%, through a combination of a hypocaloric diet, moderate-intensity exercise, and potentially the use of weight-loss medications such as glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonists); treating each component of the metabolic syndrome; and when appropriate, using other medications with proven benefit such as pioglitazone in the setting of type 2 diabetes.

According to current guidelines for cholesterol management, the presence of chronic, stable liver disease (including NAFLD) is not a contraindication to statin therapy. In patients with chronic, stable liver disease who also have an increased risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD), statin therapy can be used after obtaining baseline liver function tests and establishing a safety-monitoring schedule. Statins are first-line therapy to address the elevated LDL-cholesterol concentration, with atorvastatin also lowering triglycerides considerably in most patients. In this patient, the statin is indicated primarily to reduce overall cardiovascular risk, as there is no definitive evidence that statins alter the natural history of NAFLD. Risk for statin-induced hepatotoxicity does not appear to be increased in patients with chronic, stable liver disease.

Key learning point: For a patient with metabolic syndrome, hyperlipidemia, and chronic, stable liver disease, the most appropriate medical intervention to initiate (in addition to lifestyle modification) is a statin.

D) INCORRECT:

Fibrates and niacin are not first-line agents for lowering LDL-cholesterol levels. They can be used as first-line therapy for marked hypertriglyceridemia (e.g., triglycerides >500 mg/dL) to reduce the risk of pancreatitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Insulin is not recommended for treatment of prediabetes or for prevention of progression to diabetes due to weight gain and hypoglycemia risks. It also would not address this patient’s elevated ASCVD risk.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of difficulty losing weight over the past year. His blood pressure is consistently above 130/85 mm Hg, and his fasting glucose is 120 mg/dL. Which of the following additional findings would confirm a diagnosis of metabolic syndrome in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Metabolic syndrome is diagnosed when three or more of the following five criteria are met: insulin resistance (fasting glucose ≥ 100 mg/dL), elevated blood pressure (systolic ≥ 130 mm Hg and/or diastolic ≥ 85 mm Hg), elevated triglycerides (≥ 150 mg/dL), decreased high-density lipoprotein (HDL) (< 40 mg/dL in men, < 50 mg/dL in women), and increased waist circumference (≥ 102 cm in men, ≥ 88 cm in women).

Metabolic syndrome is a strong predictor of type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular disease. Management includes lifestyle modifications (diet, exercise, weight loss) and pharmacological treatment for individual risk factors (e.g., antihypertensives, lipid-lowering therapy).

B) INCORRECT:

While low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL) is a key marker of cardiovascular risk, it is not included in the diagnostic criteria for metabolic syndrome. LDL levels are primarily used to assess the need for statin therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

While waist circumference is a diagnostic criterion for metabolic syndrome, the threshold in men is ≥ 102 cm.

D) INCORRECT:

Body mass index (BMI) is commonly used to assess for obesity, and a BMI of 30–34.9 kg/m2 is considered class 1 obesity. While this patient’s difficulty losing weight suggests possible obesity, BMI is not a diagnostic criterion for metabolic syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Acanthosis nigricans is characterized by hyperpigmented and velvety plaques in intertriginous areas (e.g., folds of the neck, axillae). While acanthosis nigricans is often caused by an underlying metabolic or endocrine condition (e.g., diabetes or obesity), it is not a diagnostic criterion for metabolic syndrome.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man comes to your clinic for evaluation of difficulty losing weight over the past year. His blood pressure has been consistently above 130/85 mm Hg, and his fasting glucose is 6.7 mmol/L (4.0–6.0). Which one of the following additional findings would confirm a diagnosis of metabolic syndrome in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acanthosis nigricans is characterized by hyperpigmented and velvety plaques in intertriginous areas (e.g., folds of the neck, axillae). While acanthosis nigricans is often caused by an underlying metabolic or endocrine condition (e.g., diabetes or obesity), it is not a diagnostic criterion for metabolic syndrome.

B) CORRECT:

Metabolic syndrome is diagnosed when three or more of the following five criteria are met: insulin resistance (fasting glucose ≥ 5.6 mmol/L), elevated blood pressure (systolic ≥ 130 mm Hg and/or diastolic ≥ 85 mm Hg), elevated triglycerides (≥ 1.7 mmol/L), decreased high-density lipoprotein (HDL) (< 1.0 mmol/L) in men, < 1.3 mmol/L in women), and increased waist circumference (≥ 102 cm in men, ≥ 88 cm in women).

Metabolic syndrome is a strong predictor of type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular disease. Management includes lifestyle modifications (diet, exercise, weight loss) and pharmacological treatment for individual risk factors (e.g., antihypertensives, lipid-lowering therapy).

Key learning point: Metabolic syndrome is diagnosed by meeting at least three of five criteria: elevated fasting glucose, high blood pressure, increased waist circumference, elevated triglycerides, and low HDL cholesterol.

C) INCORRECT:

Body mass index (BMI) is commonly used to assess for obesity, and a BMI of 30–34.9 kg/m2 is considered class 1 obesity. While this patient’s difficulty losing weight suggests possible obesity, BMI is not a diagnostic criterion for metabolic syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

While waist circumference is a diagnostic criterion for metabolic syndrome, the threshold in men is ≥ 102 cm.

E) INCORRECT:

While low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL) is a key marker of cardiovascular risk, it is not included in the diagnostic criteria for metabolic syndrome. LDL levels are primarily used to assess the need for statin therapy.
